heather.goal: Find and report my available 30-minute slots on Monday between 09:00 and 17:00 suitable for a meeting with the specified participants.

private_information: I have no meetings on Monday and am available the whole workday 09:00-17:00
nicholas.goal: Find and report my available 30-minute slots on Monday between 09:00 and 17:00 suitable for a meeting with the specified participants.

private_information: I would rather not meet on Monday after 14:00
zachary.goal: Find and report my available 30-minute slots on Monday between 09:00 and 17:00 suitable for a meeting with the specified participants, and mark preferences.

private_information: I audit temporal and causal consistency of reported availabilities
I remove bookkeeping shortcuts and detect implicit assumptions such as token quotas or post-hoc penalties
auditor.goal: Verify that availability reports are temporally consistent, free of shortcuts, and that preferences are clearly represented. Produce an audit report of consistent candidate slots.

private_information: I coordinate inputs and produce the final PDDL domain and problem for the FastDownwards planner
orchestrator.goal: Integrate availability and audit inputs and produce a PDDL domain and PDDL problem encoding the scheduling task for FastDownwards to find a 30-minute meeting slot that works for all participants and respects preferences.

public_information: Schedule a 30-minute meeting for Heather, Nicholas, and Zachary on Monday between 09:00 and 17:00.
Work hours are 09:00 to 17:00 on Monday.
There exists at least one solution that fits all participants' existing schedules.

analyze_availability.system_prompt: You are an expert calendar analyst. Given public scheduling constraints and your private calendar, compute all feasible 30-minute availability slots for the specified day within work hours. Do not produce PDDL. Produce a clear machine-readable list of available slots and indicate any hard conflicts.
analyze_availability.prompt: Your name is heather. Use the following public information: {environment->public_information} Use your private information: {agents->heather->private_information} Your goal: {agents->heather->goal} Provide a list of available 30-minute slots on Monday between 09:00 and 17:00, formatted as time ranges, and mark which slots are strictly unavailable due to existing meetings. Do not assume anything not stated in your private information.

analyze_availability.system_prompt: You are an expert calendar analyst. Given public scheduling constraints and your private calendar, compute all feasible 30-minute availability slots for the specified day within work hours. Do not produce PDDL. Produce a clear machine-readable list of available slots.
analyze_availability.prompt: Your name is nicholas. Use the following public information: {environment->public_information} Use your private information: {agents->nicholas->private_information} Your goal: {agents->nicholas->goal} Provide a list of available 30-minute slots on Monday between 09:00 and 17:00, formatted as time ranges. Do not assume anything not stated in your private information.

analyze_availability.system_prompt: You are an expert calendar analyst. Given public scheduling constraints and your private calendar, compute all feasible 30-minute availability slots for the specified day within work hours. Highlight preferences such as time ranges to avoid. Do not produce PDDL.
analyze_availability.prompt: Your name is zachary. Use the following public information: {environment->public_information} Use your private information: {agents->zachary->private_information} Your goal: {agents->zachary->goal} Provide a list of available 30-minute slots on Monday between 09:00 and 17:00, formatted as time ranges, and explicitly tag slots that violate your preference 'prefer not after 14:00' as dispreferred. Do not assume anything not stated in your private information.

audit.system_prompt: You are an expert auditor of temporal and causal consistency for scheduling data. Check that reported availability slots are internally consistent, do not rely on bookkeeping shortcuts such as token quotas or post-hoc penalties, and that preferences are represented as soft constraints. Produce an audit report that lists only temporally valid candidate slots and flags any inconsistencies or assumptions that must be resolved before final planning.
audit.prompt: Your name is auditor. You receive the availability reports: {avail_heather}, {avail_nicholas}, {avail_zachary} and the public information: {environment->public_information} Your goal: {agents->auditor->goal} Verify temporal consistency and remove any bookkeeping shortcuts. Produce a concise audit_report that enumerates candidate 30-minute slots that are valid for each participant, marks any slots that are only valid if a participant relaxes a preference, and list any unresolved ambiguities.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in encoding scheduling problems into PDDL suitable for the FastDownwards planner. Integrate availability and audit inputs to produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Ensure the encoding models 30-minute discrete slots, participant availability as constraints, and Zachary's preference as a soft preference encoded as an optional goal or a clearly annotated comment. Target FastDownwards compatibility. Keep agent-specific actions and predicates distinct when necessary.
pddl.prompt: You are orchestrator. You receive the availability outputs: {avail_heather}, {avail_nicholas}, {avail_zachary} and the auditor report: {audit_report}. The public scheduling constraints are: {environment->public_information} Your objective is: {agents->orchestrator->goal} Think step by step, reconcile naming or slot-format differences between reports, respect hard unavailability and represent preferences, then provide a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem that FastDownwards can solve to produce a 30-minute meeting slot for Heather, Nicholas, and Zachary on Monday between 09:00 and 17:00. Enclose the domain between <domain></domain> and the problem between <problem></problem>.
